natural problem: If we count by $3\text{'s}$ starting with $1,$ the following sequence is obtained: $1,$ $4,$ $7,$ $10,$ $\dots.$ What is the $100^\text{th}$ number in the sequence?
natural solution: Since the successive terms of the sequence increase by $3,$ we relate the sequence to nearby multiples of $3$ and display the table below. Compare each of the terms of the sequence with the multiple of $3$ directly below it.

Notice that each term of the sequence is $2$ less than the corresponding multiple of $3$ directly below it. Since the $100^\text{th}$ multiple of $3$ is $300,$ the corresponding term of the sequence is $300-2=\boxed{298}.$ $$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. seq n = 1 + 3 * (n - 1)"
shows  "seq 100 = 298"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If we count by $3\text{'s}$ starting with $1,$ the following sequence is obtained: $1,$ $4,$ $7,$ $10,$ $\dots.$ What is the $100^\text{th}$ number in the sequence? The final Answer is 298
 ### Proof
 Since the successive terms of the sequence increase by $3,$ we relate the sequence to nearby multiples of $3$ and display the table below. Compare each of the terms of the sequence with the multiple of $3$ directly below it.
 Notice that each term of the sequence is $2$ less than the corresponding multiple of $3$ directly below it. Since the $100^\text{th}$ multiple of $3$ is $300,$ the corresponding term of the sequence is $300-2=\boxed{298}.$ $$
 \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \text{order of terms} & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & \dots & 100 \\ \hline \text{terms of sequence} & 1 & 4 & 7 & 10 & \dots & ? \\ \hline \text{multiples of 3} & 3 & 6 & 9 & 12 & \dots & (300)\\
 \hline \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. seq n = 1 + 3 * (n - 1)"
shows  "seq 100 = 298"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a sequence where the nth term is given by $1 + 3 * (n - 1)$, find the 100th term. The final answer is 298.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f(1) = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f(n+1) = f(n) + 3"
shows  "f 100 = 298"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If we count by $3\text{'s}$ starting with $1,$ the following sequence is obtained: $1,$ $4,$ $7,$ $10,$ $\dots.$ What is the $100^\text{th}$ number in the sequence? The final Answer is 298
 ### Proof
 Since the successive terms of the sequence increase by $3,$ we relate the sequence to nearby multiples of $3$ and display the table below. Compare each of the terms of the sequence with the multiple of $3$ directly below it.
 Notice that each term of the sequence is $2$ less than the corresponding multiple of $3$ directly below it. Since the $100^\text{th}$ multiple of $3$ is $300,$ the corresponding term of the sequence is $300-2=\boxed{298}.$ $$
 \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \text{order of terms} & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & \dots & 100 \\ \hline \text{terms of sequence} & 1 & 4 & 7 & 10 & \dots & ? \\ \hline \text{multiples of 3} & 3 & 6 & 9 & 12 & \dots & (300)\\
 \hline \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f(1) = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f(n+1) = f(n) + 3"
shows  "f 100 = 298"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined on the natural numbers such that $f(1)=1$ and for all $n \geq 1$, $f(n+1)=f(n)+3$. What is the value of $f(100)$? The final answer is 298.

a_2.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "a 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. a (Suc n) = a n + 3"
shows  "a 100 = 298"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If we count by $3\text{'s}$ starting with $1,$ the following sequence is obtained: $1,$ $4,$ $7,$ $10,$ $\dots.$ What is the $100^\text{th}$ number in the sequence? The final Answer is 298
 ### Proof
 Since the successive terms of the sequence increase by $3,$ we relate the sequence to nearby multiples of $3$ and display the table below. Compare each of the terms of the sequence with the multiple of $3$ directly below it.

 \hline \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "a 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. a (Suc n) = a n + 3"
shows  "a 100 = 298"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A sequence $a$ is defined recursively by $a(0) = 1$ and $a(n+1) = a(n) + 3$ for all natural numbers $n$. What is the value of $a(100)$? The final answer is $298$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> nth (map (\<lambda>n. 3*n - 2) [1..]) (n - 1) = 3*n - 2"
shows  "nth (map (\<lambda>n. 3*n - 2) [1..]) 99 = 298"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If we count by $3\text{'s}$ starting with $1,$ the following sequence is obtained: $1,$ $4,$ $7,$ $10,$ $\dots.$ What is the $100^\text{th}$ number in the sequence? The final Answer is 298
 ### Proof
 Since the successive terms of the sequence increase by $3,$ we relate the sequence to nearby multiples of $3$ and display the table below. Compare each of the terms of the sequence with the multiple of $3$ directly below it.
 Notice that each term of the sequence is $2$ less than the corresponding multiple of $3$ directly below it. Since the $100^\text{th}$ multiple of $3$ is $300,$ the corresponding term of the sequence is $300-2=\boxed{298}.$ $$
 \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \text{order of terms} & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & \dots & 100 \\ \hline \text{terms of sequence} & 1 & 4 & 7 & 10 & \dots & ? \\ \hline \text{multiples of 3} & 3 & 6 & 9 & 12 & \dots & (300)\\
 \hline \end{array} $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> nth (map (\<lambda>n. 3*n - 2) [1..]) (n - 1) = 3*n - 2"
shows  "nth (map (\<lambda>n. 3*n - 2) [1..]) 99 = 298"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the 100th term in a sequence where each term is defined by the formula $3n - 2$ for all natural numbers $n > 0$. The final answer is 298.
